data.text: Considering Panniers for a Bikepacking Trip?

I have a typical bikepacking setup, but am considering panniers for the flexibility of being able to carry more food/water to avoid the limitation of resupplying almost daily. Currently I have my sleeping gear up front, a full frame bag and 16.5 liter saddle bag which. While I do like the concept, I'm coming to accept that panniers might be more practical for the trip duration I'm getting into (currently on a six week trip). Anyone think I should reconsider the switch? Or want to convince me its the right thing to do? Any suggestions for panniers? I probably only need small ones, and definitely only for the rear.

I resisted rear paniers over a seat bag,until recently, when I needed the same food carrying capacity you seek .... I ditched the seat bag and went with a Topeak EXP MTX Trunk Bag ..... Overall I'd have to say the lower slung weight was actually preferable over the seat bag.... Albeit less aerodynamic and waterproof (easily made better with a drybag) .....
data.author: Graham Burt
Graham Burt

data.text: Local lover panniers
data.author: Karl Mellacher

data.text: Do it. Saves a lot of faff. I spent the last year touring with a few variations of a frame bag type set up. I found packing the seat bag (in my case 16.5L Ortlieb) to be a hassle overall. To pack it well I usually had to remove it from the bike to squeeze my sleeping quilt and mat back in properly. You can't over-pack these seat packs either, otherwise they will sag/wiggle behind. I missed the simplicity of a few small panniers to easily remove/reattach and store food in without thinking so much about how and whether it will fit. From a weight perspective the ortlieb seat pack (empty) weighed about 800g. The tourtec rack I put on recently weighs 450g and the two Ortlieb panniers about 450g each. That minimal weight increase isn't worth considering and it won't change the way I ride and where I ride. While I can see a streamlined bikepacking rig may work for someone on a short tour of a few days or a race where little food is being carried, it's otherwise far simpler and more sensible/practical to use a few panniers. Don't get caught out by the marketing and social media hype showing all the new bike-packing bags. A few pictures of previous and current rig.
data.author: Peter Gostelow

data.text: Totally agree I do bike pack on short trips but front panniers mounted on the back is a convenient compromise together with a half frame bag if needed
data.author: Grant McKern

data.text: Current set up now. Two small ortlieb panniers on rear (clothes in one pannier, food/stove in other). Tent on rear. Sleeping mat and quilt in front dry bag.
data.author: Peter Gostelow

data.text: similar to my setup. But i do have a bikepacking saddlebag, for shorter trips too. Still searching for an affordable lightweight tent tho, because Vango i have now uses too much space.

data.text: yeah this is more or less what I'm thinking of. What capacity are the panniers you have?

data.text: what's your tent budget?
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: i would say somewhere in the $250 ballpark, maybe up to $300 if i stretch it. But it has to be available in Europe. And be packable and light enough to be carried in a backpack if i want to use it for hiking. AND 2-person. AND freestanding. AND with Side entrance. AND good enough for tall ppl cause I'm 6'3". And and and... I like Nemo Hornet or BA Copper Spur, but way above my price range.
data.author: Ivan Perak

data.text: I think each is 12.5 litre. They are 18 years old with about 50,000km of use in them. Simple and waterproof.
data.author: Peter Gostelow

data.text: look at the offerings from trekkertent. I have the stealth 1. They make others, and as they're custom made and can make minor modifications like to accommodate your height.

data.text: i will check it out, tx
data.author: Ivan Perak

data.text: I leave the saddle bag at home for long trips. I go with two Ortlieb Front Roller panniers on the back, as well as a 13 liter Ortlieb dry bag on top of the rear rack. Lots of room to spare in the dry bag
data.author: Nols Bundubiker

data.text: this is like my set up also. I’m traditionally a cycle tourer that started to do more off-road and bike packing. I have an xs frame so gives me limited frame space, triangle bag holds my water so I can carry more. I tried all the bikepacking stuff and reverted back to panniers on the rear and hold my tent on the handlebars. it’s just more tidy, easier to find stuff and gives me plenty of space. Not sure if it’s just because it’s what I’m used to but it feels so much more organised especially in the rain.
data.author: Dana Fisher

data.text: This is exactly what I was going to suggest doing! 👌
data.author: Dave Henderson

data.text: Previous set up. I used a Carradice saddlebag up front to store food. It worked well for this but the faff of the seat pack remained.
data.author: Peter Gostelow

data.text: This one the Carradice saddlebag was replaced by carrying the tent on the front. That worked better than it being in the saddlebag as it was before, but I still missed an easy place to pack larger/bulky food items.
data.author: Peter Gostelow

data.text: I currently carry my sleeping gear up front in a 13l dry bag. So I'd have all the space in the panniers for other things, and would likely go from full frame to half frame bag to fit water bottles.

data.text: Well i was never supporting this system like placing a gear rack on the seat. You make the bicycle more stable to keep the bagage low so just have a rack and the weight is about the same to have this rack. And with panniers there is more comfort.
data.author: Rutger van den Hoofdakker

data.text: Panniers were always the smart option for bike touring. Don't wait any longer.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: I’m traditionally a cycle tourer that started to do more off-road I tried the bike packing set up but I have an xs frame so gives me limited frame space, my triangle bag holds my water so I can carry more but otherwise I’ve reverted back to panniers on the rear and hold my tent on the handlebars. it’s just more tidy, easier to find stuff and gives me plenty of space. Not sure if it’s just because it’s what I’m used to but it feels so much more organised especially in the rain.
data.author: Dana Fisher

data.text: I do exactly that
data.author: Jill Wright

data.text: Don't sweat the pannier thing. I did the Baja Divide route with smallish panniers front and back on my Surly ECR 29"x3". I like the lower center of gravity and extra capacity the panniers gave me. I had zero problems with the panniers. I just don't see what all the fuss is about. I like having extra space for water and things (essential on the Divide) but the main idea is it saves me having to shoe-horn my load back into the bags every morning. Much easier to have a more relaxed start to my day without sweating over every last cubic centimeter of bags space. I also did the math and determined that the weight of bottle brackets and seat bags really didn't end up saving me anything meaningful over a lightweight rack with lightweight panniers.
data.author: Lee Carruthers

data.text: I agree I crossed 5000 miles of America and parts of the Divide with panniers, The South Downs Way, The King Alfred’s Way, the Cymro North to South Wales all with panniers and as you say a lot less faff with all that stuffing and because of my XS bike frame I can only carry small water bottles so my triangle bag has a camel sac in was perfect 👍🏻
data.author: Dana Fisher

data.text: I couldn't change to bikepacking gear. I like the luxury of extra space. Currently I carried tent and sleeping gear in 1 pannier and clothing and sandals etc in the other. In my rear rack bag i carry my stove and all my food. My bar bag has waterproofs and other easily accessible gear. Total weight is generally around 13kg
data.author: David O'Donnell

data.text: I've always toured with panniers. Max weight 35lb but I usually managed with 25. I never camped. Panniers are fine off road too, IME. You occasionally will have a bit of a tight squeeze. My usual set up. Big handlebar bag for camera etc. Two big Ortlieb rolltops. 26y old at this stage. Carradice saddle bag for stove etc., if I want it. I put particular things I want together in separate plastic bags in the panniers. This works fine. I've done a lot of tours.
data.author: Gearóid Ó Laoi

data.text: Just because you carry panniers does not mean that you cannot run with them half (or more) empty most of the time. This leaves plenty of room for food items or water bottles if you are going to be in the wilds for a few days. There are a number of companies that do panniers for off road travel. These sit much higher and pass over rough ground and low scrub easily.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: oh, can you recommend one the off road panniers? Sounds like what I want! Thanks!
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: This article might be useful to you. https://www.cyclingabout.com/bikepacking-panniers-offroad-adventures/ There are reviews of some bikepacking panniers on Youtube. I think I saw one for the Arkel Drylites

data.text: the arkel drylite seems like a great option. Saw someone else recommend them here too.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: I'm a cycle tourist rather than a bike packer and love my panniers. I don't think you can get better than Ortlieb. That are waterproof and I have found them to be durable and come in all sorts of variations.
data.author: Jenny Currie

data.text: My friend and Warmshowers guest has titanium bike ,6kg gear and a well stocked credit card. Went round the world. However I prefer panniers front and back lots of empty space for quick packing. Do not overfill!!
data.author: Neil Wilson

data.text:
https://www.arkel-od.com/dry-lites/
Dry-Lites Saddle bags - Waterproof saddle bags | By Arkel
arkel-od.com
data.author: Adma Thopmson

data.text: You find yourself in the same position that touring cyclists did 100 years ago. The only thing known then was what is called "bikepacking" today. Racks and panniers came along and tying everything to the frame and forks went away. Panniers offer better handling, easier packing, more capacity, and overall a better experience. As in many fields, bicycling suffers the introduction of concepts that were tired and found wanting. When we see a "new" concept it never hurts to do a little research before we give up our hard-earned financial resources. I saw an advertisement for a shaft drive bicycle. That failed just about 100 years ago, also.
data.author: Bill Heimann

data.text: I've heard that referred to as a hybrid setup: handlebar bag, frame bag, small rear panniers. Seems like an excellent balance
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: Why not panniers? i am in control all of the time.
data.author: Rutger van den Hoofdakker

data.text: Panniers all the way. I rode around the world in 1978-80 with just rear panniers... Make sure your heels clear the panniers, if you have big feet ( I have US 14 /Euro 48) it can be a problem. If you stay in a hotel on the 3rd floor and have to carry your bags up to the room, 3 or 4 bags will be easier than 11. I have done bike packing for up to one week, ( love the minimalist stuff), but longer than that, the only logical choice is panniers. I like only rear, have seen a lot of front and back panniers on the road, they usually have way too much stuff, Don't even know what's in the bottom of some of their bags.
data.author: Robert Gex

data.text: Here I am in the middle of the photo in 1979 going up the Nile in Egypt.
data.author: Robert Gex

data.text: Yay panniers! Ortliebs have served us well. On and off road. Overnights and year long trips. Easy to pack and access . Easy to take off if you need to carry bike up 3 flights of stairs in Mongolian hotel without elevator hotel, easy to stow things securely under tent fly..
data.author: Lori Lewis

data.text: Carradice are a great option, Front panniers on the rear are a good compromise.

data.author: Scott Jones

data.text: If you use panniers, you can still use a frame bag. It's certainly very convenient for tools or wet weather gear, so you don't have to rummage through panniers when you need it.
data.author: Matthew Signorini
